channel.title: Nature
channel.description: Nature is the foremost international weekly scientific journal in the world and is the flagship journal for Nature Portfolio. It publishes the finest peer-reviewed research in all fields of science and technology on the basis of its originality, importance, interdisciplinary interest, timeliness, accessibility, elegance and surprising conclusions. Nature publishes landmark papers, award winning news, leading comment and expert opinion on important, topical scientific news and events that enable readers to share the latest discoveries in science and evolve the discussion amongst the global scientific community.
channel.dc:rights: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.
channel.prism:copyright: © 2023 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: From the archive: harmful insects, and Michael Faraday battles jargon
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02866-1

Snippets from Nature’s past.
item.dc:title: From the archive: harmful insects, and Michael Faraday battles jargon

item.title: Tasmanian tiger RNA is first to be recovered from an extinct animal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02953-3

Genetic sequences from a museum specimen offer fresh clues about the physiology of thylacines, which went extinct in the 1930s.
item.dc:title: Tasmanian tiger RNA is first to be recovered from an extinct animal
item.dc:creator: Miryam Naddaf

item.title: Forever chemicals: don’t ban the harmless ones
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02913-x

Forever chemicals: don’t ban the harmless ones
item.dc:title: Forever chemicals: don’t ban the harmless ones
item.dc:creator: Ole John Nielsen

item.title: Another reason to love remote working: it’s good for the planet
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02918-6

The more people do their jobs from home, the more they cut their greenhouse-gas emissions.
item.dc:title: Another reason to love remote working: it’s good for the planet

item.title: When authors play the predatory journals’ own game
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02911-z

When authors play the predatory journals’ own game
item.dc:title: When authors play the predatory journals’ own game
item.dc:creator: Jeremiah Joven Joaquin
Hazel T. Biana

item.title: My double life as a cell biologist and crime writer
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02933-7

Achieving tenure enabled Frances Brodsky to focus on her research, write three novels and launch a journal.
item.dc:title: My double life as a cell biologist and crime writer
item.dc:creator: Miles Lizak

item.title: Bringing space rocks back to Earth could answer some of life’s biggest questions
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02905-x

Safe delivery of samples from an asteroid on 24 September will be the start of a global scientific journey — but similar missions need support.
item.dc:title: Bringing space rocks back to Earth could answer some of life’s biggest questions
item.dc:creator: Meenakshi Wadhwa

item.title: AlphaFold tool pinpoints protein mutations that cause disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02943-5

Researchers have adapted the AI network to search for genetic changes linked to ill health.
item.dc:title: AlphaFold tool pinpoints protein mutations that cause disease

item.title: AI can help to speed up drug discovery — but only if we give it the right data
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02896-9

Artificial-intelligence tools that enable companies to share data about drug candidates while keeping sensitive information safe can unleash the potential of machine learning and cutting-edge lab techniques, for the common good.
item.dc:title: AI can help to speed up drug discovery — but only if we give it the right data
item.dc:creator: Marissa Mock
Suzanne Edavettal
Christopher Langmead
Alan Russell

item.title: FedEx for your cells: this biological delivery service could treat disease
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02906-w

Researchers want to know why cells produce tiny packages called vesicles — and whether these bundles could be used for therapy.
item.dc:title: FedEx for your cells: this biological delivery service could treat disease
item.dc:creator: Alison Abbott

item.title: Why the pandemic treaty risks becoming COVID-19 groundhog day
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 19 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02904-y

Talks are stalling, but everyone benefits when the fruits of vaccine and drugs research are shared equitably.
item.dc:title: Why the pandemic treaty risks becoming COVID-19 groundhog day

item.title: Retraction Note: New land-use-change emissions indicate a declining CO<sub>2</sub> airborne fraction

item.title: Cholinergic neurons trigger epithelial Ca<sup>2+</sup> currents to heal the gut
item.content:encoded:

Cholinergic neurons trigger epithelial Ca2+ currents to heal the gut
item.dc:title: Cholinergic neurons trigger epithelial Ca<sup>2+</sup> currents to heal the gut
item.dc:creator: Afroditi Petsakou
Yifang Liu
Ying Liu

Norbert Perrimon

item.title: ‘We’re losing our glaciers’: scientist caches ice from the Antarctic climate record
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02910-0

As coordinator and caretaker at an ice-core facility, Rebecca Pyne preserves these precious records of past climate.
item.dc:title: ‘We’re losing our glaciers’: scientist caches ice from the Antarctic climate record
item.dc:creator: James Mitchell Crow

item.title: Super-precise CRISPR tool enters US clinical trials for the first time
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02836-7

Base editing, which makes specific changes to a cell’s genome, is put to the test in CAR-T-cell treatments for leukaemia.
item.dc:title: Super-precise CRISPR tool enters US clinical trials for the first time
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: World’s most powerful X-ray laser will ‘film’ chemical reactions in unprecedented detail
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02874-1

Upgraded laser in California will produce one million X-ray pulses per second to study ultrafast processes at the atomic level.
item.dc:title: World’s most powerful X-ray laser will ‘film’ chemical reactions in unprecedented detail
item.dc:creator: Katherine Bourzac

item.title: NIH upholds controversial plan to step up oversight of foreign collaborators
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02923-9

The US biomedical agency tweaked its new policy after an outcry from researchers, but will forge ahead.
item.dc:title: NIH upholds controversial plan to step up oversight of foreign collaborators
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Geneticist J. Craig Venter: ‘I consider retirement tantamount to death’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02907-9

The human genome ‘maverick’ talks sequencing the ocean, setting up a health-screening company after checking his own genes — and why he has no plans to stop.
item.dc:title: Geneticist J. Craig Venter: ‘I consider retirement tantamount to death’
item.dc:creator: Heidi Ledford

item.title: A new human species? Mystery surrounds 300,000-year-old fossil
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02924-8

A chinless jawbone from eastern China that displays both modern and archaic features could represent a new branch of the human family tree.
item.dc:title: A new human species? Mystery surrounds 300,000-year-old fossil
item.dc:creator: Dyani Lewis

item.title: Promotion pathways: how scientists can chart their industry career trajectory
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02908-8

Confused about promotion opportunities after moving to industry? Here are some pointers.
item.dc:title: Promotion pathways: how scientists can chart their industry career trajectory
item.dc:creator: Sandeep Ravindran

item.title: Nickelates join the club of high-temperature superconductors
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02857-2

A nickel-based compound has shown evidence of a superconducting state at a temperature of 80 kelvin. The material bridges a gap between other nickelates and a notable class of superconductor containing copper.
item.dc:title: Nickelates join the club of high-temperature superconductors
item.dc:creator: Matthias Hepting

item.title: Waste product from wood finally used to make glue
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02864-3

Scientists have had limited success in converting lignin, a structural component of plants, into high-value products. The discovery that lignin can be used as a wood glue could be a game-changer for biorefineries.
item.dc:title: Waste product from wood finally used to make glue
item.dc:creator: Charles E. Frazier

item.title: Catching proteins at play: the method revealing the cell’s inner mysteries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 18 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02909-7

Cryo-electron tomography is a hugely promising tool in visual proteomics — if researchers can work out what they are seeing.
item.dc:title: Catching proteins at play: the method revealing the cell’s inner mysteries
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: A vaccine against the cervical-cancer virus shows its prowess
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02830-z

In a large trial, not a single participant developed a serious precancerous lesion caused by a vaccine-targeted viral type.
item.dc:title: A vaccine against the cervical-cancer virus shows its prowess

item.title: This parrot taps out beats — and it custom-builds its instruments
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02829-6

Male palm cockatoos prefer certain types of percussion tool, which they create themselves from branches and seed pods.
item.dc:title: This parrot taps out beats — and it custom-builds its instruments

item.title: I train farmers to use plant science in the fight against climate change
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02914-w

Plant breeder and geneticist Prince Matova helps farmers in drought-prone areas to increase their yields.
item.dc:title: I train farmers to use plant science in the fight against climate change
item.dc:creator: Clemence Manyukwe

item.title: This alternative way to measure research impact made judges cry with joy
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02877-y

Research managers, citizen scientists, librarians and technicians rarely make it onto author lists. But an initiative to assess their hidden contributions to team science moved some judging panel members to tears.
item.dc:title: This alternative way to measure research impact made judges cry with joy
item.dc:creator: Dom Byrne

item.title: Octopuses used in research could receive same protections as monkeys
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02887-w

For the first time in the United States, research with cephalopods might require approval by an ethics committee.
item.dc:title: Octopuses used in research could receive same protections as monkeys
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: Daily briefing: NASA’s input could be ‘a teachable moment’ for UFO-hunters
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02927-5

It might be good for science if NASA got involved with the search for aliens on Earth, life-changing cystic fibrosis treatment wins the Breakthrough Prize and a tiny jumping robot that is powered by explosions.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: NASA’s input could be ‘a teachable moment’ for UFO-hunters
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Libya floods: how climate change intensified the death and devastation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02899-6

Climate change, civil war and international sanctions all contributed to the devastation caused by some of Libya’s worst flooding ever, researchers say.
item.dc:title: Libya floods: how climate change intensified the death and devastation
item.dc:creator: Michael Marshall

item.title: First global survey reveals who is doing ‘gain of function’ research on pathogens and why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 15 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02873-2

An analysis of the controversial work indicates that a one-size-fits-all regulation strategy will have consequences.
item.dc:title: First global survey reveals who is doing ‘gain of function’ research on pathogens and why
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: Author Correction: Accurate medium-range global weather forecasting with 3D neural networks
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06545-z

Author Correction: Accurate medium-range global weather forecasting with 3D neural networks
item.dc:title: Author Correction: Accurate medium-range global weather forecasting with 3D neural networks
item.dc:creator: Kaifeng Bi
Lingxi Xie
Hengheng Zhang
Xin Chen
Xiaotao Gu
Qi Tian

item.title: This insect-sized robot can carry 22 times its own weight
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02900-2

The four-legged miniature machine is powered by tiny explosions.
item.dc:title: This insect-sized robot can carry 22 times its own weight
item.dc:creator: Katharine Sanderson

item.title: Psychedelic drug MDMA moves closer to US approval following success in PTSD trial
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02886-x

Long-awaited trial data show drug is effective at treating post-traumatic stress disorder in a diversity of people.
item.dc:title: Psychedelic drug MDMA moves closer to US approval following success in PTSD trial
item.dc:creator: Sara Reardon

item.title: A test of artificial intelligence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02822-z

As debate rages over the abilities of modern AI systems, scientists are still struggling to effectively assess machine intelligence.
item.dc:title: A test of artificial intelligence
item.dc:creator: Michael Eisenstein

item.title: UFO sightings: how NASA can bring science to the debate
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02893-y

An astrophysicist who advised the agency talks to Nature about ways to bring rigour to reports of ‘unidentified anomalous phenomena’.
item.dc:title: UFO sightings: how NASA can bring science to the debate
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Witze

item.title: Why Japan is building its own version of ChatGPT
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02868-z

Some Japanese researchers feel that AI systems trained on foreign languages cannot grasp the intricacies of Japanese language and culture.
item.dc:title: Why Japan is building its own version of ChatGPT
item.dc:creator: Tim Hornyak

item.title: Daily briefing: AI detects risk of Parkinson’s from retinal images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02903-z

Artificial intelligence diagnoses and predicts the risk of developing Parkinson’s disease, heart failure and more from images of a person’s retinas. Plus, a ‘Pandora’s box’ of new protein shapes has been discovered and why breast cancer often spreads to the spine.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: AI detects risk of Parkinson’s from retinal images
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Human trials of artificial wombs could start soon. Here’s what you need to know
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02901-1

US regulators will consider clinical trials of a system that mimics the womb, which could reduce deaths and disability for babies born extremely preterm.
item.dc:title: Human trials of artificial wombs could start soon. Here’s what you need to know
item.dc:creator: Max Kozlov

item.title: How my broken elbow made the ableism of computer programming personal
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02885-y

Amy Ko’s accident gave her an insight into the degree to which her discipline caters mainly to non-disabled people, reinspiring her to invent more accessible programming languages.
item.dc:title: How my broken elbow made the ableism of computer programming personal
item.dc:creator: Amy Ko

item.title: Life-changing cystic fibrosis treatment wins US$3-million Breakthrough Prize
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 14 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02890-1

Trio of scientists who developed the combination drug Trikafta are among the winners of five major awards in life sciences, physics and mathematics.
item.dc:title: Life-changing cystic fibrosis treatment wins US$3-million Breakthrough Prize
item.dc:creator: Zeeya Merali

item.title: Uncovering new families and folds in the natural protein universe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06622-3

Uncovering new families and folds in the natural protein universe
item.dc:title: Uncovering new families and folds in the natural protein universe

item.title: A mussel-inspired glue for more sustainable sticking
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02891-0

A soya-oil-derived adhesive matches the strength of conventional glues, and reassessing the extent and impacts of childhood malnutrition.
item.dc:title: A mussel-inspired glue for more sustainable sticking
item.dc:creator: Nick Petrić Howe
Shamini Bundell

item.title: The maths of how we wait in crowded places
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02828-7

Experiments at a simulated railway platform show people space themselves out regardless of obstacles.
item.dc:title: The maths of how we wait in crowded places

item.title: Bacterial pathogens deliver water- and solute-permeable channels to plant cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06531-5

The bacterial effector proteins of the AvrE family function as membrane channels in plant cells, enabling the passage of water and solutes from host cells to support pathogen growth, and disrupting the viability of the host cell.
item.dc:title: Bacterial pathogens deliver water- and solute-permeable channels to plant cells
item.dc:creator: Kinya Nomura
Felipe Andreazza
Jie Cheng
Ke Dong
Pei Zhou
Sheng Yang He

item.title: DNA-based programmable gate arrays for general-purpose DNA computing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06484-9

Generic single-stranded oligonucleotides used as a uniform transmission signal can reliably integrate large-scale DNA integrated circuits with minimal leakage and high fidelity for general-purpose computing.
item.dc:title: DNA-based programmable gate arrays for general-purpose DNA computing
item.dc:creator: Hui Lv

item.title: A foundation model for generalizable disease detection from retinal images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06555-x

RETFound, a foundation model for retinal images that learns generalizable representations from unlabelled images, is trained on 1.6 million unlabelled images by self-supervised learning and then adapted to disease detection tasks with explicit labels.
item.dc:title: A foundation model for generalizable disease detection from retinal images

item.title: Clustering-predicted structures at the scale of the known protein universe
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06510-w

The novel Foldseek clustering algorithm defines 2.30 million clusters of AlphaFold structures, identifying remote structural similarity of human immune-related proteins in prokaryotic species.
item.dc:title: Clustering-predicted structures at the scale of the known protein universe
item.dc:creator: Inigo Barrio-Hernandez

item.title: Phase-dependent growth of Pt on MoS<sub>2</sub> for highly efficient H<sub>2</sub> evolution
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06339-3

We report the production of MoS2 nanosheets with high phase purity, showing that the 2H-phase templates facilitate epitaxial growth of Pt nanoparticles, whereas the 1T′ phase supports single-atomically dispersed Pt atoms.
item.dc:title: Phase-dependent growth of Pt on MoS<sub>2</sub> for highly efficient H<sub>2</sub> evolution

item.title: Causes and consequences of child growth faltering in low-resource settings
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06501-x

Analysis of data from 33 longitudinal cohorts from low- and middle-income countries indicates that conditions during pre-conception, pregnancy and the first few months of life are crucial in determining the risk of growth faltering in young children.
item.dc:title: Causes and consequences of child growth faltering in low-resource settings

Seungmi Yang
Pablo Penataro Yori

item.title: Single-cell brain organoid screening identifies developmental defects in autism
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06473-y

We develop a high-throughput CRISPR screening system in cerebral organoids and identify vulnerable cell types and gene regulatory networks associated with autism spectrum disorder from single-cell transcriptomes and chromatin modalities.
item.dc:title: Single-cell brain organoid screening identifies developmental defects in autism
item.dc:creator: Chong Li
Jonas Simon Fleck
Catarina Martins-Costa
Thomas R. Burkard
Jan Themann
Marlene Stuempflen
Angela Maria Peer
Ábel Vertesy
Jamie B. Littleboy

Ulrich Elling
Gregor Kasprian
Nina S. Corsini

Juergen A. Knoblich

item.title: Learning heterogeneous reaction kinetics from X-ray videos pixel by pixel
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06393-x

Analysis of a large dataset of scanning transmission X-ray microscopy images of carbon-coated lithium iron phosphate nanoparticles shows that the heterogeneous reaction kinetics of battery materials can be learned from such videos pixel by pixel.
item.dc:title: Learning heterogeneous reaction kinetics from X-ray videos pixel by pixel
item.dc:creator: Hongbo Zhao
Haitao Dean Deng
Alexander E. Cohen
Jongwoo Lim
Yiyang Li
Dimitrios Fraggedakis
Benben Jiang
Brian D. Storey
William C. Chueh
Richard D. Braatz
Martin Z. Bazant

item.title: Structural basis for thioredoxin-mediated suppression of NLRP1 inflammasome
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06532-4

Structural and mutational studies and cellular assays show that the inflammasome sensor NLRP1 forms a complex with thioredoxin, which acts as a negative regulator of inflammasome activity.
item.dc:title: Structural basis for thioredoxin-mediated suppression of NLRP1 inflammasome
item.dc:creator: Zhikuan Zhang
Takuma Shibata
Akiko Fujimura
Jiro Kitaura
Kensuke Miyake
Umeharu Ohto
Toshiyuki Shimizu

item.title: Child wasting and concurrent stunting in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06480-z

An analysis of longitudinal cohort data across diverse populations suggests that the incidence of wasting between birth and 24 months is higher than previously thought, and highlights the role of seasonal factors that affect child growth.
item.dc:title: Child wasting and concurrent stunting in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:creator: Andrew Mertens

item.title: Projected decline in European bumblebee populations in the twenty-first century
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06471-0

A quantitative study of past, present and future ecological suitability of Europe for bumblebees finds that for 38–76% of species now considered non-threatened, suitable territory could decrease by at least 30% by 2061–2080.
item.dc:title: Projected decline in European bumblebee populations in the twenty-first century
item.dc:creator: Guillaume Ghisbain
Wim Thiery
François Massonnet
Diana Erazo
Pierre Rasmont
Denis Michez
Simon Dellicour

item.title: Flatband λ-Ti<sub>3</sub>O<sub>5</sub> towards extraordinary solar steam generation
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06509-3

A route to greatly elevate joint densities of states by introducing a flat-band electronic structure is demonstrated, showing metallic λ-Ti3O5 powders have a high solar absorptivity and offering insights into access to cost-effective solar-to-steam generation.
item.dc:title: Flatband λ-Ti<sub>3</sub>O<sub>5</sub> towards extraordinary solar steam generation
item.dc:creator: Bo Yang
Zhiming Zhang
Peitao Liu
Xiankai Fu
Jiantao Wang

Haile Yan

Xing-Qiu Chen
Liang Zuo

item.title: Shape memory polymer with programmable recovery onset
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06520-8

A four-dimensional printable shape memory hydrogel with shape-shifting onset adjustable by changing the programming conditions is reported.
item.dc:title: Shape memory polymer with programmable recovery onset
item.dc:creator: Chujun Ni
Di Chen
Yu Yin
Xin Wen

item.title: Structural mobility tunes signalling of the GluA1 AMPA glutamate receptor
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06528-0

Calcium-permeable GluA1 AMPA glutamate receptors are structurally and functionally distinct from the prototypical GluA2-containing AMPA receptors, impacting their role in signal transmission, synaptic plasticity and learning.
item.dc:title: Structural mobility tunes signalling of the GluA1 AMPA glutamate receptor
item.dc:creator: Danyang Zhang
Josip Ivica
James M. Krieger
Hinze Ho
Keitaro Yamashita
Imogen Stockwell
Rozbeh Baradaran
Ondrej Cais
Ingo H. Greger

item.title: A cross-species proteomic map reveals neoteny of human synapse development
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06542-2

A study presents a cross-species proteomic map of synapse development in neocortex and reveals that the human postsynaptic density assembly develops two to three times slower than that in macaques and mice.
item.dc:title: A cross-species proteomic map reveals neoteny of human synapse development
item.dc:creator: Li Wang
Kaifang Pang

Arnold R. Kriegstein

item.title: A vertebral skeletal stem cell lineage driving metastasis
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06519-1

Vertebral osteoblasts in mouse and human are formed from a precursor skeletal stem cell population that is distinct from long bone skeletal stem cells in function, location and transcriptional programme.
item.dc:title: A vertebral skeletal stem cell lineage driving metastasis
item.dc:creator: Jun Sun
Lingling Hu
Seoyeon Bok
Alisha R. Yallowitz

item.title: Molecular basis of methyl-salicylate-mediated plant airborne defence
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06533-3

Aphid-transmitted viruses encode proteins that suppress the plant airborne defence response—which is triggered by volatile chemicals released by neighbouring plants after aphid attack—and the plants consequently become less repellent to aphids and more suitable for aphid survival, infestation and viral transmission.
item.dc:title: Molecular basis of methyl-salicylate-mediated plant airborne defence
item.dc:creator: Qian Gong
Yunjing Wang
Linfang He
Fan Huang
Danfeng Zhang
Yan Wang
Xiang Wei
Meng Han

Yiguo Hong
Yule Liu

item.title: Sustainably sourced components to generate high-strength adhesives
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06335-7

We present a sustainably sourced adhesive system, with performance comparable to that of current industrial products, made from epoxidized soy oil, malic acid and tannic acid, all biomass derived, low cost and readily available.
item.dc:title: Sustainably sourced components to generate high-strength adhesives
item.dc:creator: Clayton R. Westerman
Bradley C. McGill
Jonathan J. Wilker

item.title: Early-childhood linear growth faltering in low- and middle-income countries
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06418-5

A pooled analysis of longitudinal studies in low- and middle-income countries identifies the typical age of onset of linear growth faltering and investigates recurrent faltering in early life.
item.dc:title: Early-childhood linear growth faltering in low- and middle-income countries
item.dc:creator: Jade Benjamin-Chung

item.title: Tropical Atlantic multidecadal variability is dominated by external forcing
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/s41586-023-06489-4

Anthropogenic and volcanic aerosols dominate multidecadal variability in aspects of the tropical Atlantic climate, such as sea surface temperatures, Sahel rainfall and hurricanes.
item.dc:title: Tropical Atlantic multidecadal variability is dominated by external forcing
item.dc:creator: Chengfei He
Amy C. Clement
Sydney M. Kramer
Mark A. Cane
Jeremy M. Klavans
Tyler M. Fenske
Lisa N. Murphy

item.title: What scientists need to do to accelerate progress on the SDGs
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02808-x

Drilling down into why the UN Sustainable Development Goals are so hard to achieve, and showing policymakers pathways to follow, will help the planet and save lives.
item.dc:title: What scientists need to do to accelerate progress on the SDGs
item.dc:creator: Shirin Malekpour
Cameron Allen
Ambuj Sagar
Imme Scholz
Åsa Persson
J. Jaime Miranda

item.title: Invitation to a dance
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02664-9

The next move.
item.dc:title: Invitation to a dance
item.dc:creator: Bo Balder

item.title: AI detects eye disease and risk of Parkinson’s from retinal images
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02881-2

Researchers have developed a model trained similarly to ChatGPT that can be adapted to evaluate multiple health conditions.
item.dc:title: AI detects eye disease and risk of Parkinson’s from retinal images
item.dc:creator: Mariana Lenharo

item.title: Genetic dissection of plants’ airborne defences
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02770-8

Plants communicate with neighbouring plants to activate an airborne defence against aphids. However, the genetic pathway underlying this defence mechanism is unknown. A signalling cascade centred around the gaseous form of the chemical methyl salicylate was found to control this interaction between plants.
item.dc:title: Genetic dissection of plants’ airborne defences

item.title: Daily briefing: COVID boosters are back
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02898-7

Some countries are rushing to roll out autumn COVID-19 vaccination campaigns. Plus, why Morocco’s earthquake was so deadly and how lab leaders in the UK are grappling with a lack of postdocs.
item.dc:title: Daily briefing: COVID boosters are back
item.dc:creator: Flora Graham

item.title: Do you really know the way the world is heading? Take this quiz on plans to save humanity
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02806-z

The United Nations has ambitious aims to end poverty and clean up the planet by 2030. See whether you know how the world is faring on the Sustainable Development Goals.
item.dc:title: Do you really know the way the world is heading? Take this quiz on plans to save humanity
item.dc:creator: Ehsan Masood
Richard Van Noorden

item.title: Ancient-human fossils sent to space: scientists slam ‘publicity stunt’
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02882-1

The decision to send hominin bones on a commercial spaceflight has raised eyebrows among human-evolution researchers.
item.dc:title: Ancient-human fossils sent to space: scientists slam ‘publicity stunt’
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway

item.title: Breast cancer often spreads to the spine — newfound stem cell can explain why
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02851-8

A stem cell that contributes to vertebra formation also encourages the growth of tumours that move to the backbone from elsewhere.
item.dc:title: Breast cancer often spreads to the spine — newfound stem cell can explain why
item.dc:creator: Saima Sidik

item.title: Bacteria deliver water channels to infect plants
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02767-3

A wide range of harmful bacteria introduce proteins into plant cells. Some of these proteins move to the cell membrane and serve as channels for water and nutrients, creating favourable conditions for bacterial growth beside plant cells.
item.dc:title: Bacteria deliver water channels to infect plants
item.dc:creator: Gwyn A. Beattie

item.title: ‘A Pandora’s box’: map of protein-structure families delights scientists
item.content:encoded:
Nature, Published online: 13 September 2023; doi:10.1038/d41586-023-02892-z

Never-before-seen forms and unexpected connections between proteins revealed by analysis of their shapes.
item.dc:title: ‘A Pandora’s box’: map of protein-structure families delights scientists
item.dc:creator: Ewen Callaway
